Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Paper-based surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy (P-SERS) for biosensing using inkjet-fabricated devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to create a new and transformative class of lateral-flow bioanalytical microsystems based on inkjet fabrication and paper-based surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy (P-SERS) for multi-analyte detection. While paper-based sensors have recently emerged for simplistic assays, the proposed approach of fabricating bio-functionalized surfaces and optofluidic SERS detection elements using inkjet printing enables sensitive and sophisticated assays that are extraordinarily low in cost and simple to perform.

The intellectual merit of this effort is the establishment of the fundamental components that enable the emergence of new methodologies in sophisticated paper-based assays. These components include: (i) inkjet-based functionalization of cellulose paper with biomolecules and
plasmonic nanostructures, (ii) Raman reporter molecules that are highly reactive with metal nanostructures, and (iii) a quantitative understanding of the mass transport advantages of paper-based fluidic biosensors.

The broader impacts of this research are centered around the transformative approach to bioanalytics enabled by the P-SERS paradigm. The incredibly low cost of the proposed P-SERS
microsystems combined with the unprecedented ease of use will lead to a broad range of new applications that require highly sensitive, low-cost disposable analytical devices, including applications in disaster response, at-home health care, and infectious disease screening. In addition, the unique properties of the P-SERS technology enable it to be incorporated as an educational tool at all stages of learning and in any environment. Research opportunities and engineering design projects built around inkjet fabrication and paper-based analytics will be created for underrepresented high school students and for undergraduate engineering students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we investigated the capabilities of inkjet-fabricated surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) sensors on paper and membrane substrates: (1) to overcome the world-to-chip interface challenges of existing SERS systems, (2) to enable cleanup of complex samples using the inherent separation capabilities of paper and membranes, and (3) to reduce the number of steps in SERS biosensors using lateral flow competitive displacement.  The outcomes of the work are as follows:

1.Paper SERS devices eliminate the world-to-chip interface challenge.  SERS sensors on rigid substrates and in microfluidic channels are not able to interface directly with the sample in the field, inhibiting field-based or point-of-care based sensing.  We demonstrated that paper sensors allow efficient sample collection through swabbing (trace analyte on a surface) and dipping (liquid samples). We demonstrated the collection and immediate detection of pesticides from surfaces and solutions. (Yu and White, Analyst, 2013, Hoppmann, et al, Methods, 2013)

2. Sample cleanup and detection with lateral-flow separation. Detecting analytes in complex samples is problematic for SERS.  We utilized lateral-flow paper chromatography for sample cleanup to improve detection capabilities.  To illustrate this inherent advantage of paper and membrane SERS, we detected narcotics masked with fluorescent cutting agents and melamine in infant formula. (Yu and White, Analyst, 2013, Hoppmann, Applied Spectroscopy, 2014)

3. Sample cleanup and detection with vertical flow separation.  Lateral-flow chromatography can be slow and may not work for all samples and/or analytes.  As an alternative we investigated a vertical-flow system in which a membrane stack separates the analyte from the interfering sample components.  We demonstrated detection of the antimicrobial flucytosine in serum (as well as whole blood) using a vertical flow separation system.  This demonstration serves as a proof-of-concept for a point-of-care therapeutic drug monitoring system. (Berger, et al., Analytica Chimica Acta, 2017)

4. Sample-to-answer SERS biosensors through competitive displacement.  Typical labeled biosensors require multiple reagent additions and washes.  We engineered a nucleic acid hybridization assay in which the biomarker in the sample displaces a probe, causing it to flow laterally along a channel to the SERS detection zone.  We are in the process of transitioning from a microfluidic proof-of-concept to a lateral-flow and/or vertical-flow implementation on paper or membranes. (Yazdi, et al., Analytical Chemistry, 2013)

With these outcomes, we have advanced the field of SERS sensors for both chemical and biological sensing applications.  In particular, we have advanced the usability of SERS sensors, which we anticipate will lead to sensing and diagnostics applications at the point-of-sample.
